facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 752 of 1957 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 752 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated January 8, 1954, of the Madras High Court in Second Appeal No. 312 of 1949.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated January 8, 1954 of Madras High Court in Second Appeal No. 312 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated January 8, 1954, of the Madras High Court in Second Appeal No. 312 of 1949. V. Viswanatha Sastri and P. V. B. Tatachari, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 16, 1961 by WANCHOO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 16. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-This appeal on a certificate granted by the Andhra Pradesh High Court raises the question of the interpretation of s. 44-B 1  of the Madras, Hindu Religious Endowments Act No. II of 1927  hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: Appeal raised on certificate granted by Andhra Pradesh High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal on a certificate granted by the Andhra Pradesh High Court raises the question of the interpretation of s. 44-B 1  of the Madras, Hindu Religious Endowments Act No. II of 1927  hereinafter called the Act . The point arises in this way.

facts.text: Property in dispute originally granted in inam to ancestors of predecessors-in-interest of plaintiffs-respondents for performance of parak service in temples of village Panyam in Nandyal Taluk of Kurnool District.

anchor.surface_text: The property in dispute was originally granted in inam to the ancestors of the predecessors-in-interest of the plaintiffs-respondents for the performance of parak service in the pagodas  temples  of village Panyam in Nandyal Taluk of the Kurnool District.

facts.text: Grantees alienated considerable portion of the inam land.

anchor.surface_text: The grantees of the land in this inam alienated a companysiderable portion of it and also ceased to perform the parak service.

facts.text: Grantees ceased to perform parak service.

anchor.surface_text: The grantees of the land in this inam alienated a companysiderable portion of it and also ceased to perform the parak service. In companysequence, the trustees of the temples at Panyam applied.

facts.text: Trustees of temples at Panyam applied to Sub-Collector under s. 44-B (2)(a)(i) and (ii) for resumption of lands and regrant to temples.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence, the trustees of the temples at Panyam applied. to the Sub-Collector under s. 44-B  2   a   i  and  ii  of the Act for the resumption of the lands and their regrant to the temples on the ground that the holders of the inam had alienated the property and had failed to perform the service required of them.

facts.text: Revenue Divisional Officer, Nandyal held that inam granted on condition of parak service, breach by failure to perform service and alienation within s.44-B(2)(a)(i).

anchor.surface_text: An inquiry was companyducted into these allegations, and it was held by the Revenue Divisional Officer, Nandyal, that the inam had been granted on the companydition of parak service being rendered and that there had been breach of the companydition on failure to perform the service and also that the lands companyprised in the inam had been alienated in a manner falling within s. 44-B  2   a   i  of the Act.

facts.text: Revenue Divisional Officer ordered resumption of inam lands and regrant to temples in Panyam village.

anchor.surface_text: On these findings the resumption of the inam lands was ordered and the inam was re-granted to the temples in Panyam village.

facts.text: Alienees appealed to Collector but failed.

anchor.surface_text: The alienees took the matter in appeal to the Collector but failed. Thereupon they filed the suit out of which the present appeal has arisen

facts.text: Alienees filed suit contending revenue authorities had no jurisdiction under s.44-B.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon they filed the suit out of which the present appeal has arisen and their main companytention was that. the revenue authorities had numberjurisdiction to order the resumption of the inam under s. 44-B.

facts.text: Suit resisted by trustees (defendants).

anchor.surface_text: The suit was resisted by the trustees who were defendants to it

facts.text: Trustees' case: inam was religious service inam or personal inam burdened with service, justifying resumption under s.44-B.

anchor.surface_text: and their case was that the, inam was a religious service inam in the sense of being emoluments for the performance of service and alternatively that even if the grant was a personal inam, burdened with the performance of parak service, the grant was companyditional on the performance of the service and as there was breach of this obligation, the resumption and re- grant were justified under s. 44-B.

facts.text: Certain preliminary facts not in dispute: inam grant comprised both warams.

anchor.surface_text: Certain preliminary facts are number in dispute number. It has been found by all the companyrts that the inam grant companyprised both the warams.

facts.text: Grant to inamdar was personal though burdened with parak service, not a service inam constituting emoluments of office.

anchor.surface_text: It has also been found that the grant to the inamdar was personal to him though burdened with parak service and number a service inam in the sense of the inam companystituting emoluments of any office.

facts.text: Trial court held case does not fall within s.44-B, decreed for plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: On the finding that the inam was a personal inam burdened with service to the temple the trial companyrt held that the case did number fall within s. 44-B of the Act.

facts.text: District court confirmed trial court decree.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the district companyrt companyfirmed the decree of the trial companyrt.

facts.text: In High Court second appeal, finding on both warams not contested, personal inam burdened with service conceded.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court on second appeal the finding as to the inam being of both warams was number companytested and it was companyceded that it was a personal inam burdened with service.

facts.text: High Court held against trustees, dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held against the trustees and dismissed the appeal. Thereupon the trustees who are the appellants before us applied for a certificate which was granted to them

facts.text: Trustees applied for certificate, granted, leading to Supreme Court appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the trustees who are the appellants before us applied for a certificate which was granted to them and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: Section 44-B introduced in Madras Hindu Religious Endowments Act No. II of 1927 in 1934.

anchor.surface_text: It is in this background that we have to examine s. 44-B  1  introduced in the Act in 1934 and see whether personal inams burdened with service are included within its ambit.

facts.text: Prior to s.44-B, enforcement via Board's Standing Order 54.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to the introduction of s. 44-B in the Act, the enforcement of a companydition of a grant in favour of charitable and religious institutions in Madras was by taking recourse to Boards Standing Order 54.

concepts.interpretation: Wide words do not include personal inams burdened with service; confined to service inams or inams directly for temple/math or whole income for charity.

anchor.surface_text: The distinction between a grant for an office to be remunerated by the use of land and a grant of land burdened with service is well known in Hindu law. The former is a case of a service grant and is resumable when the service is number performed. The latter is number a service grant as such but a grant in favour of a person though burdened with service and its resumption will depend upon whether the circumstances in which the grant was made establish a companydition that it was resumable if the service was number performed  see Shrimant Lakhamgouda Basavprabhu Sardesai v. Raosaheb Baswantrao alias Annasaheb Subedar and Others  1  .

concepts.interpretation: Service grant fully resumable on breach; personal burdened grant resumable only if condition expressly resumable, typically only service portion.

issues.text: the question of the interpretation of s. 44-B 1  of the Madras, Hindu Religious Endowments Act No. II of 1927

anchor.surface_text: s. 44-B 1  of the Madras, Hindu Religious Endowments Act No. II of 1927  hereinafter called the Act . The point arises in this way. The property in dispute was originally granted in inam to the ancestors of the predecessors-in-interest of the plaintiffs-respondents for the performance of parak service in the pagodas  temples  of village Panyam in Nandyal Taluk of the Kurnool District.

issues.text: whether the case would fall within the four corners of s. 44-B even if the inam which was granted in the present case was a personal inam of both warams burdened with service to the temple

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court on second appeal the finding as to the inam being of both warams was number contested and it was companyceded that it was a personal inam burdened with service. The only question that was agitated there was whether the case would fall within the four corners of s. 44-B even if the inam which was granted in the present case was, a personal inam of both warams burdened with service to the temple.

issues.text: whether a personal inam burdened with service to a temple can be said to come within the meaning of the words any inam granted for the performance of a service connected with a temple

anchor.surface_text: The question for consideration is whether a personal inam burdened with service to a temple can be said to companye within the meaning of the words any inam granted for the performance of a service companynected with a temple. It is urged that the words used in s. 44-B  1  are of very wide import and any personal grant of land howsoever large, if it is burdened with some service to a temple howsoever small, would be within the meaning of these words and would therefore companye within the terms of s.44-B  1 .

anchor.surface_text: The question for consideration is whether a personal inam burdened with service to a temple can be said to come within the meaning of the words any inam granted for the performance of a service connected with a temple. It is urged that the words used in s. 44-B 1 are of very wide import and any personal grant of land howsoever large, if it is burdened with some service to a temple howsoever small, would be within the meaning of these words and would therefore come within the terms of s.44-B 1 .

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court rightly repelled wide construction; Hindu law distinction, legislative history, harmonious reading exclude personal burdened inams

arguments.claim: Distinction in Hindu law: service grant (office remunerated by land) resumable on non-performance; personal grant burdened with service resumable only if expressly conditional

anchor.surface_text: The distinction between a grant for an office to be remunerated by the use of land and a grant of land burdened with service is well known in Hindu law. The former is a case of a service grant and is resumable when the service is not performed. The latter is not a service grant as such but a grant in favour of a person though burdened with service and its resumption will depend upon whether the circumstances in which the grant was made establish a condition that it was resumable if the service was not performed see Shrimant Lakhamgouda Basavprabhu Sardesai v. Raosaheb Baswantrao alias Annasaheb Subedar and Others 1 .

arguments.claim: s.44-B covers only service grants, not personal grants burdened with service, based on pre-1934 BSO 54 practice

anchor.surface_text: The question therefore is whether s. 44-B covers only the first type of grant, namely, a service grant and not a personal grant burdened with service. Prior to the introduction of s. 44-B in the Act, the enforcement of a condition of a grant in favour of charitable and religious institutions in Madras was by taking recourse to Boards Standing Order 54.

arguments.claim: Amendment to BSO 54 dividing inams into class (a) service/charity inams under Act and class (b) others under BSO 54 shows s.44-B limited to service inams

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that on the introduction of s. 44-B 1 in the Act., B.S.O. 54 was amended and religious and charitable inams which were all governed till then by it were divided into two classes, namely- a inams granted for the performance of a charity or service connected with a Hindu math or temple and b inams not falling under class a . Inams falling under class a were to be governed by the provisions of the Act while inams falling under class b were to be governed by B.S.O. 54 as heretofore.

arguments.claim: Wide interpretation absurd: large personal inams with slight service would be fully resumed and regranted to temple

anchor.surface_text: This amendment would also show that all religious inams, i.e., inams which had some connection howsoever slight with a temple or other religious institution were not to be governed by s. 44-B and only those inams which were granted for the performance of a charity or service connected with a Hindu math or temple were to be dealt with under s. 44-B while others would still be governed by B.S.O. 54.

arguments.claim: s.44-B(2)(a)(iii) on resumption if temple ceases or service impossible does not sensibly apply to personal burdened inams

anchor.surface_text: This conclusion is in our opinion enforced if we look at cl. of s. 44-B 2 a which permits resumption of an inam on the ground that either the math or temple has ceased to exist or the service in question has in any way become impossible of performance.

arguments.claim: s.44-B(2)(f)(i) re-grant to temple presumes whole inam for service, not personal element

anchor.surface_text: Further if we look at s. 44-B 2 f i , it provides that where an inam is resumed under s. 44-B 1 it shall be re-granted as an endowment to the temple or math concerned

arguments.claim: s.44-B(2)(f)(ii) re-grant to Board if temple ceases overlooks personal part of burdened inam

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, s. 44- B 2 f ii provides that where the math or temple has ceased to exist and an inam is resumed on that ground it shall be re-granted as an endowment to the Board

holdings.text: The High Court has repelled this wide construction of the words used in s. 44-B(1), and we think rightly.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has repelled this wide construction of the words used in s. 44-B 1 , and we think rightly. The distinction between a grant for an office to be remunerated by the use of land and a grant of land burdened with service is well known in Hindu law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide literal reading rejected in light of established Hindu law distinction between service grants and personal grants burdened with service.

holdings.text: The distinction between a grant for an office to be remunerated by the use of land and a grant of land burdened with service is well known in Hindu law. The former is a case of a service grant and is resumable when the service is not performed. The latter is not a service grant as such but a grant in favour of a person though burdened with service and its resumption will depend upon whether the circumstances in which the grant was made establish a condition that it was resumable if the service was not performed.

anchor.surface_text: The distinction between a grant for an office to be remunerated by the use of land and a grant of land burdened with service is well known in Hindu law. The former is a case of a service grant and is resumable when the service is number performed. The latter is number a service grant as such but a grant in favour of a person though burdened with service and its resumption will depend upon whether the circumstances in which the grant was made establish a companydition that it was resumable if the service was number performed  see Shrimant Lakhamgouda Basavprabhu Sardesai v. Raosaheb Baswantrao alias Annasaheb Subedar and Others  1  .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Citing established Hindu law precedent distinguishing types of grants and consequences of breach.

holdings.text: We therefore agree with the High Court that this history affords a clue to the interpretation of s. 44-B(1) and suggests that though the words used in s. 44-B are open to a wide interpretation, the intention was to bring within its purview only those inams which were granted directly to the temple and also those inams which were granted for the performance of a charity or service connected with a math or temple, i.e., service inams or such inams the whole income of which was for charity and not those inams which were personal inams though burdened with some service to a temple or math.

anchor.surface_text: This amendment would also show that all religious inams, i.e., inams which had some connection howsoever slight with a temple or other religious institution were not to be governed by s. 44-B and only those inams which were granted for the performance of a charity or service connected with a Hindu math or temple were to be dealt with under s. 44-B while others would still be governed by B.S.O. 54. We therefore agree with the High Court that this history affords a clue to the interpretation of s. 44-B 1 and suggests that though the words used in s. 44-B are open to a wide interpretation, the intention was to bring within its purview only those inams which were granted directly to the temple and also those inams which were granted for the performance of a charity or service connected with a math or temple, i.e., service inams or such inams the whole income of which was for charity and not those inams which were personal inams though burdened with some service to a temple or math.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative history, amendment to B.S.O. 54 dividing inams into class (a) service/charity under Act and class (b) others under B.S.O. 54, indicates limited scope.

holdings.text: This conclusion is in our opinion enforced if we look at cl. of s. 44-B(2)(a) which permits resumption of an inam on the ground that either the math or temple has ceased to exist or the service in question has in any way become impossible of performance.

anchor.surface_text: This conclusion is in our opinion enforced if we look at el. of s. 44-B  2  a  which permits resumption of an inam on the ground that either the math or temple has ceased to exist or the service in question has in any way become impossible of performance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.44-B(2)(a)(iii) would lead to absurd result if applied to personal burdened inams, as personal portion should not be resumed if temple ceases.

holdings.text: Further if we look at s. 44-B(2)(f)(i), it provides that where an inam is resumed under s. 44-B(1) it shall be re-granted as an endowment to the temple or math concerned.

anchor.surface_text: Further if we look at s. 44-B  2  f  i , it provides that where an inam is resumed under s. 44-B  1  it shall be re-granted as an endowment to the temple or math concerned

holdings.reasoning_summary: Re-grant provision presupposes entire inam was for temple service, not including personal element in burdened grants.

holdings.text: Similarly, s. 44-B(2)(f)(ii) provides that where the math or temple has ceased to exist and an inam is resumed on that ground it shall be re-granted as an endowment to the Board.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, s. 44- B 2  f  ii  provides that where the math or temple has ceased to exist and an inam is resumed on that ground it shall be re-granted as an endowment to the Board

holdings.reasoning_summary: Re-grant to Board ignores personal portion of burdened inam, confirming exclusion.

holdings.text: Therefore, the view taken by the High Court that s. 44-B(1), though on a wide interpretation it might also include personal inams burdened with service, is really confined to inams directly granted to the temple or service inams for the purpose of a temple or math or inams the whole of the income of which is meant for charity and does not include personal inams burdened with service, is correct. Such inams would continue to be dealt with under B.S.O. 54, class b as introduced by the amendment to that Order.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesis of textual, historical, purposive, and harmonious interpretations confirms narrow scope of s.44-B(1); revenue authorities lacked jurisdiction in this case.

outcome.relief_summary: Held that s. 44-B does not cover personal inams burdened with service; resumption and re-grant to temples not justified under the section; High Court view upheld

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has repelled this wide construction of the words used in s. 44-B 1 , and we think rightly. The distinction between a grant for an office to be remunerated by the use of land and a grant of land burdened with service is well known in Hindu law.

Therefore, the view taken by the High Court that s. 44-B 1 , though on a wide interpretation it might also include personal inams burdened with service, is really confined to inams directly granted to the temple or service inams. for the purpose of a temple or math or inams the whole of the income of which is meant for charity and does number include personal inams burdened with service, is companyrect. Such inams would continue to be dealt with under B.S.O. 54, class b as introduced by the amendment to that Order.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 explicitly articulates the distinction between a service grant (inam for office remunerated by land) and personal grant burdened with service as well known in Hindu law, directly grounding concept c7.

anchor.surface_text: The distinction between a grant for an office to be remunerated by the use of land and a grant of land burdened with service is well known in Hindu law. The former is a case of a service grant and is resumable when the service is number performed. The latter is number a service grant as such but a grant in favour of a person though burdened with service and its resumption will depend upon whether the circumstances in which the grant was made establish a companydition that it was resumable if the service was number performed  see Shrimant Lakhamgouda Basavprabhu Sardesai v. Raosaheb Baswantrao alias Annasaheb Subedar and Others  1  .

Therefore, the view taken by the High Court that s. 44-B 1 , though on a wide interpretation it might also include personal inams burdened with service, is really confined to inams directly granted to the temple or service inams. for the purpose of a temple or math or inams the whole of the income of which is meant for charity and does number include personal inams burdened with service, is companyrect. Such inams would continue to be dealt with under B.S.O. 54, class b as introduced by the amendment to that Order.

anchor.surface_text: This amendment would also show that all religious inams, i.e., inams which had some connection howsoever slight with a temple or other religious institution were not to be governed by s. 44-B and only those inams which were granted for the performance of a charity or service connected with a Hindu math or temple were to be dealt with under s. 44-B while others would still be governed by B.S.O. 54. We therefore agree with the High Court that this history affords a clue to the interpretation of s. 44-B 1 and suggests that though the words used in s. 44-B are open to a wide interpretation, the intention was to bring within its purview only those inams which were granted directly to the temple and also those inams which were granted for the performance of a charity or service connected with a math or temple, i.e., service inams or such inams the whole income of which was for charity and not those inams which were personal inams though burdened with some service to a temple or math.

Therefore, the view taken by the High Court that s. 44-B 1 , though on a wide interpretation it might also include personal inams burdened with service, is really confined to inams directly granted to the temple or service inams. for the purpose of a temple or math or inams the whole of the income of which is meant for charity and does number include personal inams burdened with service, is companyrect. Such inams would continue to be dealt with under B.S.O. 54, class b as introduced by the amendment to that Order.
it was burdened might have been slight, the remaining income of the inam being intended as a personal grant to the individual. Therefore when s. 44-B

anchor.surface_text: This conclusion is in our opinion enforced if we look at el. of s. 44-B  2  a  which permits resumption of an inam on the ground that either the math or temple has ceased to exist or the service in question has in any way become impossible of performance.

Therefore, the view taken by the High Court that s. 44-B 1 , though on a wide interpretation it might also include personal inams burdened with service, is really confined to inams directly granted to the temple or service inams. for the purpose of a temple or math or inams the whole of the income of which is meant for charity and does number include personal inams burdened with service, is companyrect. Such inams would continue to be dealt with under B.S.O. 54, class b as introduced by the amendment to that Order.

Therefore, the view taken by the High Court that s. 44-B 1 , though on a wide interpretation it might also include personal inams burdened with service, is really confined to inams directly granted to the temple or service inams. for the purpose of a temple or math or inams the whole of the income of which is meant for charity and does number include personal inams burdened with service, is companyrect. Such inams would continue to be dealt with under B.S.O. 54, class b as introduced by the amendment to that Order.

Therefore, the view taken by the High Court that s. 44-B 1 , though on a wide interpretation it might also include personal inams burdened with service, is really confined to inams directly granted to the temple or service inams. for the purpose of a temple or math or inams the whole of the income of which is meant for charity and does number include personal inams burdened with service, is companyrect. Such inams would continue to be dealt with under B.S.O. 54, class b as introduced by the amendment to that Order.

Such inams would continue to be dealt with under B.S.O. 54, class b as introduced by the amendment to that Order.
